Teaching Statement

2026-01-13

My teaching philosophy is grounded in the belief that motivation is a necessary precondition for learning, and that effective teaching depends on instructors actively cultivating motivation in their students. In economics, early course material provides essential foundations, but its relevance often becomes clear to students only later in the semester. The backward design of my courses is intended to bridge this gap early by first identifying the economic questions and applications that are most engaging to students, mapping those questions to their underlying economic concepts, and then designing the progression of learning objectives to build toward students’ understanding of those concepts.

I identify motivating economic questions by investing early in understanding who my students are and how economics fits into their goals. This includes learning about students’ backgrounds, interests, and career aspirations, as well as the broader institutional context—where graduates tend to work, which industries and policy environments are salient, and how economics is used outside the classroom. Drawing on this information allows me to frame material around questions that students recognize as relevant, whether those concern labor markets, housing, public policy, or firm behavior. By grounding economic analysis in settings that students can place themselves in, I lower the barrier to engagement and create a reason to care about the analytical tools introduced later in the course.

Once these motivating questions are established, I emphasize what I view as one of the central skills of economics: distilling complex real-world problems into a small set of core economic concepts. I make explicit how seemingly different issues often hinge on the same underlying ideas—such as incentives, constraints, equilibrium, and tradeoffs—and show students how formal models are built to isolate these mechanisms. This step is critical for helping students see economic theory not as abstraction for its own sake, but as a disciplined way of simplifying reality in order to reason clearly. By repeatedly mapping rich problems to a common conceptual framework, students begin to recognize structure where previously they saw complexity.

I then design the progression of learning objectives so that formal tools and mathematical reasoning are introduced precisely when they become necessary to analyze these concepts. Because students are already motivated by the question at hand and understand the conceptual role of the model, mathematical results are interpreted as statements about real-world behavior rather than as purely technical exercises. I emphasize that models must be internally consistent and economically meaningful—for example, that a prediction of negative quantities or implausible comparative statics signals a breakdown in assumptions or reasoning rather than a result to be accepted mechanically. This approach reinforces the connection between formal analysis and economic intuition, helping students develop both technical competence and sound economic judgment.
